name: Vladimir the Great
JA_events:
Expanded Kievan realm to include Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine|
Converted to Christianity and Christianized the pagan Rus'
JA_relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Otto I, Grandfather-in-law, img/hre/otto_i.jpeg

name: Sviatopolk I
JA_events:
Known as 'The Accursed', murdered his 3 brothers to seize power|
Defeated in battle by remaining brother, Yaroslav
JA_relationships: Poland, Boleslaus I, Father-in-law, img/poland/boleslaus_i.jpg

name: Yaroslav the Wise
JA_events:
Enacted code of law known as Russkaya Pravda, the Rus Truth|
Captured part of Crimea from the Byzantine Empire|
Captured Estonia with the help of Scandinavian allies
JA_relationships:
Poland, Casimir I, Brother-in-law, img/poland/casimir_i.png|
France, Henry I, Son-in-law, img/france/henry_i.jpg|
England, Edgar the Ætheling, Grandson, img/england/edgar_aethling.jpg

name: Iziaslav I
JA_events:
Founded the first Kievan Eastern Orthodox monastery|
Fled during popular uprising, then returned with help from Polish|
Crowned first King of Rus' by the Pope
JA_relationships: Poland, Casimir I, Brother-in-law, img/poland/casimir_i.png

name: Sviatoslav II
JA_events:
Joined brothers Iziaslav and Vsevolod in a triumvirate of Kiev|
With support of Vsevolod, dethroned and replaced Iziaslav

name: Vsevolod I
JA_events: United the core principalities of Kiev, Chernigov, and Pereyaslav
JA_relationships:
Byzantine, Constantine IX, Brother-in-law, img/byzantine/constantine_ix.jpg|
Holy Roman Empire, Henry IV, Son-in-law, img/hre/henry_iv.jpg

name: Sviatopolk II
JA_events:
Engaged in campaigns against the Kypchaks but defeated in 1093|
Attemped compact with Chernigov by inviting Cuman raiders|
Embellished the golden-roofed St. Michael's Abbey in Kiev
JA_relationships:
Poland, Boleslaw III, Son-in-law, img/poland/boleslaw_iii.png|
Bohemia, Spytihnev II, Father-in-law, img/poland/spytihnev_ii.jpg

name: Vladimir II
JA_events:
Engaged in constant warfare with the Turkic Cumans|
Held series of congresses to unite Rus' princes against Great Steppe
JA_relationships: England, Harold Godwinson, Father-in-law, img/england/harold_godwinson.jpg

name: Mstislav I
JA_events:
Fought the Cumans, Estonians, and Lithuanians for entire reign|
After death, united Rus broke apart for four hundred years
JA_relationships:
Sweden, Inge I, Father-in-law, img/sweden/inge_i.jpg|
Denmark, Valdemar I, Grandson, img/denmark/valdemar_i.jpg|
Denmark, Eric II, Son-in-law, img/denmark/eric_ii.JPG

name: Ivan IV
JA_events:
Established the Tsardom of Russia with Moscow at the center|
Conquered Khanates of Kazan, Astrakhan, and Sibir|
Transformed Russia from medieval state to complex empire
JA_wars:
Russo-Turkish War, 1568-70|
Livonian War, 1558-83|
Russo-Crimean War, 1570-72

name: Feodor I
JA_events:
Last Rurikid Tsar of Russia|
Country administered by brother-in-law, Boris Godunov|
Dying childless, plunged Russia into the Time of Troubles

name: Boris Godunov
JA_events:
Rose through the ranks from soldier to favorite to minister|
Separated Russian Orthodox Church from Constantinople

name: Feodor II
JA_events:
Proclaimed Tsar after the death of father|
Envoys of False Dmitriy publicly read his fate in Red Square|
Boyars, disloyal to new Tsar, arrested, strangled, and poisoned him

name: False Dmitry
JA_events:
One of three pretenders claiming to be son of Ivan the Terrible|
Formed army with support of Poland, marching against Godunov|
Promised Russian Church back to Rome, inciting death by mob

name: Vasili IV
JA_events:
Plotted against False Dmitry, taking throne after his death|
Deposed and forced into a monastery, dying a prisoner

name: Michael I
JA_events:
Elected Tsar, taking Russia back from the Kingdom of Poland|
Accession marked the end of the Time of Troubles|
Conquered Siberia with help of cossacks and Stroganov family
JA_relationships: Denmark, Valdemar Christian, Son-in-law, img/sweden/valdemar_christian.jpg

name: Alexis I
JA_events:
Excommunicated Patriarch Nikon, who attempted a Greek reform|
Faced riots over salt, copper, and Cossacks led by Stenka Razin|
Ended his reign with 8,000,000 square kilometers under his rule
JA_wars:
Russo-Persian War, 1651-53|
Russo-Polish War, 1654-67|
Russo-Swedish War, 1656-58

name: Feodor III
JA_events:
Founded the academy of sciences in Zaikonospassky Monastery|
Introduced reforms such as meritocracy, Greek, and beard shaving|
Died without issue, sparking the Moscow Uprising of 1682

name: Peter I
JA_events:
Westenized Russia, traveling Europe and founding St. Petersburg|
Captured ports at Azov and Baltic Sea from Swedes and Tatars|
Transformed Russia into modern, scientific Enlightened empire
JA_wars:
Bulavin Rebellion, 1707-8|
Russo-Turkish War of 1710|
Great Northern War, 1700-21|
JA_relationships: Sweden, Charles Frederick, Son-in-law, img/hre/charles_frederick.jpg

name: Catherine I
JA_events:
Succeeded husband, since heir Alexei was convicted of treason|
Continued liberalization, opening door to female monarchs
JA_relationships: Sweden, Charles Frederick, Son-in-law, img/hre/charles_frederick.jpg

name: Peter II
JA_events:
Son of Peter I through his first wife, Charlotte Christine|
Disinclined to rule, spent time feasting and died quite young|
Last male heir of the Romanov line
JA_relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Louis Rudolph, Grandfather, img/hre/louis_rudolph.jpg

name: Anna
JA_events:
Daughter of half-brother of Peter I's invalid half-brother, Ivan V|
Continued reforms in architecture, science, and the arts|
Named grand-nephew Ivan VI heir to exclude lineage of Peter I
JA_wars:
War of the Polish Succession|
Russo-Turkish War, 1735-39
JA_relationships: Poland-Lithuania, Frederick William, Husband, img/poland/frederick_william.jpg

name: Ivan VI
JA_events:
Declared Emperor at the age of two months|
Imprisoned after a year by cousin Elizabeth, who launched a coup|
After twenty years in captivity, killed by guards during failed rescue

name: Elizabeth
JA_events:
Invested heavily in architecture, such as the Winter Palace|
Received all of Southern Finland from Sweden in Treaty of Åbo|
Died unexpectedly before defeating Prussia in Seven Years' War
JA_wars:
War of the Austrian Succession|
Seven Years' War, 1756-63

name: Peter III
JA_events:
Nephew to Elizabeth, first of Holstein-Gottorp-Romanov house|
A progressive, granted religion freedom and abolished secret police|
Overthrown by wife Princess Sophie, who became Catherine II
JA_relationships: Sweden, Charles Frederick, Father, img/hre/charles_frederick.jpg

name: Catherine II
JA_events:
Oversaw the breakup of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth|
Gained Crimea and Poland; colonized Novorossia and Alaska|
An enlightened absolutist, brought about an artistic renaissance
JA_wars:
Russo-Turkish Wars, 1768-74|
Polish-Russian War, 1792|
Russo-Persian War, 1795
JA_relationships:
Poland, Stanislaw II, Lover, img/poland/stanislaw_ii.jpg|
Sweden, Gustave IV Adolf, Cousin, img/sweden/gustav_iv_adolf.jpg

name: Paul I
JA_events:
Added eastern Georgia to the empire|
Allied with Britain and Austria against Napeolonic France|
Creating policies unfriendly to nobles, was assassinated by military
JA_relationships:
Prussia, Frederick II Eugene, Father-in-law, img/germany/frederick_eugene.jpg|
Netherlands, William II, Son-in-law, img/dutch/william_ii.jpg

name: Alexander I
JA_events:
King of Poland and Grand Duke of Finland during unity periods|
Napoleon's army collapsed during invasion, losing 500,000 men|
Joined Holy Alliance with Austria and Prussia to combat revolutions
JA_wars:
Anglo-Russian War, 1807-1812|
Finnish War, Sweden, 1808-9|
Russo-Persian War, 1804-13

name: Nicholas I
JA_events:
Seized the last territories in the Caucasus held by Persia|
Lost Crimean War and influence over Romania, Serbia, & Black Sea|
On eve of death, Russian territory was at its zenith: 8MM sq. miles
JA_wars:
Russo-Persian War, 1826-28|
Greek War of Independence|
Crimean War, Ottomans, 1853-6
JA_relationships:
Denmark, Frederick William, Son-in-law, img/denmark/frederick_william.jpg|
Prussia, Frederick William III, Father-in-law, img/germany/frederick_william_iii.jpg

name: Alexander II
JA_events:
Emancipated Russian serfs, for which he is known as The Liberator|
Sold Alaska to the United States to prevent it from becoming British|
Pursued further expansion into Siberia, Caucasus, and Turkestain
JA_relationships:
German Confederation, Louis II, Father-in-law, img/germany/louis_ii.jpg|
German Empire, Alfred, Son-in-law, img/germany/alfred.jpg|
Greece, Alexandra, Daughter-in-law, img/greece/alexandra.jpg

name: Alexander III
JA_events:
A counter-reformer, reversed many of his father's policies|
Formed Triple Entente alliance with France and Great Britain|
JA_relationships:
Denmark, Christian IX, Father-in-law, img/denmark/christian_ix.jpg|
England, Edward VII, Brother-in-law, img/england/edward_vii.jpg|
Greece, George I, Brother-in-law, img/greece/george_i.jpg

name: Nicholas II
JA_events:
Lost influence over Manchuria and Korea to the Japanese|
Lost 3.3 million Russians during World War I, causing revolution|
Abdicated, imprisoned, and handed over to Bolsheviks for execution
JA_relationships:
Denmark, Christian IX, Grandfather, img/denmark/christian_ix.jpg|
Greece, Constantine I, Cousin, img/greece/constantine_i.jpg|
Germany, Wilhelm II, Cousin, img/germany/wilhelm_ii.jpg
